question_text: How does the degree of polymerization (DP) of cellulose influence the yield of levoglucosan during pyrolysis, and what is the underlying chemical mechanism?
standard_answer: The degree of polymerization (DP) of cellulose significantly affects levoglucosan (LG) yield during pyrolysis due to the role of glycosidic bond cleavage and intramolecular reactions. Higher DP cellulose contains more β-1,4-glycosidic bonds, whose cleavage generates glucosyl cations. These cations can undergo intramolecular nucleophilic attack by the C6 hydroxyl group, forming the stable 1,6-anhydride structure of levoglucosan. As DP increases, the probability of this intramolecular cyclization rises because longer chains provide more sites for cation formation upon bond scission. Additionally, higher DP cellulose has a more extended hydrogen-bonding network, which may stabilize intermediate cations and favor LG formation over fragmentation pathways. Experimentally, LG yield increases from ~8% for glucose (DP=1) to over 54% for high-DP cellulose, demonstrating the direct correlation between chain length and LG production. This mechanism highlights the importance of polymer architecture in controlling pyrolysis product selectivity.
